publications.title: Dynamic Role-Based Access Control for Decentralized Applications
publications.publishedAt: International Conference on Blockchain (IEEE ICBC 2020) · Sep 18, 2020
publications.description: Access control management is an integral part of maintaining the security of an application. For access control management on the Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT), available traditional access control frameworks are inadequate and are tightly coupled with the business logic, resulting in an adverse impact on the overall software quality for DLT based Decentralized Applications (dApps). In this paper, we have proposed a novel framework to implement dynamic role-based access control for dApps.

publications.title: Production Challenges of Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) based Enterprise Applications
publications.publishedAt: 2019 International Symposium on Systems Engineering (ISSE) · Feb 5, 2020
publications.description: Distributed Ledger Technology promises to solve multiple problems emergent of existing IT solutions and business processes on the intersection of trust, privacy, security, automation, authentication and authorization. However, multiple obstacles restrict the potential of the technology, specifically production-related challenges in the enterprise-centric ecosystem. The paper provides a holistic view of the top production readiness challenges of the decentralized application (dApp) for enterprise along with alternative solutions. We propose a novel approach to identify challenges and rank them.

experience.description:
As the sole fullstack developer, I was responsible for designing, developing, and launching AIpublisher.org, a journal publishing platform. My work spanned the full software development lifecycle, from gathering requirements to deployment and maintenance.

Key Contributions:

End to End Development: Built the platform’s frontend with React.js and backend with Node.js/Express.js, supported by a MySQL database.

Journal Publishing Workflow: Implemented features for article/journal submission, peer-review processes, and publication management.

Payment System: Designed and integrated a secure payment gateway to handle author payments.

Admin Back-Office Portal: Developed tools for admins to manage journals, articles, sliders, banners, and user accounts.

Security: Mitigated common vulnerabilities such as XSS, CSRF, and SQL injection to ensure application integrity.

Scalability: Optimized performance to handle increasing submission volume and user activity.

Collaboration: Worked closely with stakeholders to translate business requirements into a functional and scalable solution.

At DCKAP, I initially joined as a Frontend Developer, where I was responsible for implementing dynamic and responsive user interfaces based on mockups provided by the design team. My work focused on writing clean, efficient JavaScript code and integrating UI components to ensure seamless user experiences across the company’s products.

Key Contributions:

    Developed and maintained front-end features across various web applications.

    Collaborated closely with designers and backend developers to deliver production-ready interfaces.

    Ensured cross-browser compatibility and optimized UI performance.

As I had a strong interest in cybersecurity, I proposed and was given the opportunity to conduct security testing on one of the company’s core products. Transitioning into the role of a Penetration Tester in the final 5 months of my tenure, I identified and reported critical vulnerabilities, helping improve product security significantly.

Security Contributions:

    Discovered and documented high-impact vulnerabilities including Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) and HTML Injection.

    Provided remediation suggestions and worked with development teams to patch the identified issues.

    Enhanced overall awareness of application security within the team.

This dual-role experience allowed me to grow both as a developer and as a security enthusiast, contributing to both product quality and resilience.

projects.title: The Endless Chat App [Whatsapp clone] in Java
projects.associatedWith: Associated with Dayananda Sagar College of Engineering, BANGALORE
projects.description:
The Endless chat - a real-time chatting application, is a desktop-based application that is developed using swing and socket programming in Java. In this chat application, we aim to achieve communication among two applications, the server, and the client.

The frame for the server and the client with proper sizing, dimensions, and background color are created using the Swing library. The frame includes a header section, a dynamic text area, and a footer section. The header section comprises different icons like profile picture, video call, phone, menu icon along with showing the status of the person,i.e, typing or active now.

A text field with a button to send a message is created at the bottom of the frame along with the dynamic text area to which the messages are appended once they are sent by the user. Speech bubbles are used to display and distinguish the texts from server and client which are appended to the dynamic text area. The dynamic text area is also provided with a scroll bar to scroll through the texts.

To establish the connection between the server and the client frame, socket programming is used which is a part of networking in Java, where the client-socket and the server-socket are the classes used for establishing communication between these two applications. The messages sent from the Server are displayed towards the right side of the server’s frame and the messages received from the client are displayed towards the left side of the client’s frame.

projects.title: Survey Paper on Secure Hash Algorithm(SHA)
projects.associatedWith: Associated with Presidency University Bangalore
projects.description:
Abstract- The Secure Hash Algorithm (SHA) is a cryptographic hash function family widely used in digital signatures, password storage, and various security protocols. Developed by the National Security Agency (NSA) and published by the National 
Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), SHA ensures data integrity and authentication by producing a fixed-size hash 
value (digest) from input data of any size. The most commonly used versions include SHA-1, SHA-256, SHA-384, and SHA-512, 
each with different output sizes and cryptographic properties. Despite the cryptographic strength of SHA-256 and higher 
variants, SHA-1 has become deprecated due to vulnerabilities discovered in its collision resistance, highlighting the importance 
of ongoing research and adoption of robust hash functions in modern security practices.

Advanced use of system calls, epoll/select, polling mechanisms, and memory-mapped I/O via mmap and ioctl.

Blockchain Development
Proficient in Smart Contract Development using Solidity on Ethereum and EVM-compatible blockchains.

Developed and tested DeFi tools, airdrop automation bots, and contract interaction scripts.

Knowledgeable in web3.js, ethers.js, hardhat, and Remix IDE for deployment/testing.

Implemented blockchain arbitrage logic, token analysis tools, and automation using Python and Node.js.

Familiar with gas optimization, secure contract patterns, and basic auditing practices.

Debugging, Optimization & Tools
Advanced skills in debugging with GDB, memory tools like Valgrind (Memcheck, Callgrind), AddressSanitizer (ASan), and Electric Fence.

Used strace, ltrace, perf, ftrace, and SystemTap for profiling and tracing low-level performance issues.

Hands-on with binary analysis using objdump, readelf, nm, and core dump inspection.

Scripting & Automation
Strong scripting background in Python, Bash, and Perl, used extensively for automating system tasks, log analysis, memory tracing, performance dashboards, and test frameworks.

Built custom CLI tools for IPC testing, kernel module automation, and blockchain node monitoring.

Platforms & Toolchain
Comfortable across Linux distributions (Ubuntu, Debian, CentOS), embedded platforms (Yocto, Buildroot), and cross-compilation toolchains.

Experience with Git, SVN, Makefiles, CMake, and CI/CD systems like Jenkins and GitLab CI.

Contributed to open-source projects, kernel module integrations, and blockchain testnet deployments.
